subject: Junit extensions and logging.

messageBody:
Hi, relative newbie to junit and logging here.

I am using this diasparsoftToolkit and it has some nice features (this came
out of reading the junit recipies book
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1932394230 - this is a really good
book). The logging in the test cases is easy if you inherit from their abc,
it's just info(...), warn(...), etc. and there is other good stuff like
partially ordered tests and closure exceptions. But there may be other
things out there that I don't know about (fitness?)

The consensus seems to be that jdk logging sucks big time (seems fine to me
though at first blush)) and one should therefore use
http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/logging/ as it wraps log4j and jdk.

I also have to deal with webmacro and it's logging.

My first priority is doing the architecture for testing in a good way, so
what do you guys think about this diasparsoft stuff? Have you found
something better or equal but different? (I am introducing junit into a
small .bomb that is not terribly agile (i.e. *no* tests) and has lot's of
your typical many kloc servlets. So I can't get too carried away, but I
would like to have some of the helper stuff in junit in whatever I can foist
upon them).

After that, does the commons logging seem best and has anyone used it with
webmacro? Or should I byte the bullet and say jdk all the way?

Any pointers will be appreciated.

thanks
---
ray tayek <http://tayek.com/>, co-chair <http://www.ocjug.org/>, actively
seeking telecommuting work.
